You can bring any number of items to the market and exchange them for any other one. Note that each item is one of a kind and that means that you cannot exchange set{a,b}for set{v,a}. However, you can always exchange setxfor any sety, unless there is itemp, such thatpoccurs inxandpoccurs iny.For each item, John knows its valueci. John's sense of justice doesn't let him exchange a set of itemsxfor a set of itemsy, ifs(x) +d<s(y)(s(x)is the total price of items in the setx).During one day John can exchange only one set of items for something else. Initially, he has no items. John wants to get a set of items with the maximum total price. There are $n$ unique items, each with a value $c_i$. You can exchange sets of items for other sets, but you cannot exchange a set $x$ for a set $y$ if there is an item that is in both $x$ and $y$.  You also cannot exchange a set $x$ for a set $y$ if the total value of $x$ plus $d$ is less than the total value of $y$.

You start with no items. Find the maximum total value of a set of items you can obtain and the minimum number of days it takes to get that set.

You have a set of items, each with a value. You can trade any number of items for any other set of items, as long as no item is duplicated in the trade. You also have a fairness rule: the total value of the items you trade away must be less than or equal to the total value of the items you receive.  Find the highest total value you can achieve and the fewest trades it takes.
